Modeling and Impact.Description: Understand, guide, shape impact of computing on society/the world. Connect the role of Theory CS classes to other applications (in undergraduate CS curriculum and beyond). Model problems using appropriate mathematical concepts

Connections with other courses.Description: Explore applications in CS through multiple perspectives, including software, hardware, and theory.

Children.drawing circuits: Drawing a logical circuit to implement a compound proposition
Children.tracing circuits: Tracing a logical circuit to determine the values on output wires
Children.applications of number representations: Determining the properties of positional number representations, including overflow and bit operations

Model systems.Description: Model systems with tools from discrete mathematics and reason about implications of modelling choices.

Children.modeling clusters: Modeling data with partitions and functions
Children.data types: Selecting and representing appropriate data types and using notation conventions to clearly communicate choices
Children.linked lists: Modeling data structures, such as linked lists or trees, as recursively defined data structures

Translate.Description: Translate between different representations to illustrate a concept

Children.compound propositions and truth tables: Translating between truth tables (tables of values) and compound propositions
Children.graph representations of relations: Drawing graph representations of relations and functions e.g. Hasse diagram and partition diagram
Children.representing numbers: Representing numbers using positional representations, including decimal, binary, hexadecimal, fixed-width representations, and 2s complement
Children.translating: Translating between symbolic and English versions of statements using precise mathematical language

Problem Solving.Description: Know, select and apply appropriate computing knowledge and problem-solving techniques. Reason about computation and systems. Use mathematical techniques to solve problems. Determine appropriate conceptual tools to apply to new situations. Know when tools do not apply and try different approaches. Critically analyze and evaluate candidate solutions.

Propositional and predicate logic.Description: Reason about the truth or falsity of complicated statements using Boolean connectives, quantifiers, and basic operations.

Children.evidence for quantified statements: Determining what evidence is required to establish that a quantified statement is true or false
Children.quantified statement proofs: Evaluating quantified statements about finite and infinite domains
Children.cnf and dnf: Rewriting compound propositions using normal forms
Children.consistency: Judging whether a collection of propositions is consistent
Children.logical equivalence via laws: Judging logical equivalence of compound propositions using symbolic manipulation with known equivalences, including DeMorgan's Law
Children.logical equivalence via truth tables: Judging logical equivalence of compound propositions using truth tables
Children.variants of conditionals: Writing the converse, contrapositive, and inverse of a given conditional statement

Proof strategies and valid arguments.Description: Apply proof strategies, including direct proofs and proofs by contradiction, and determine whether a proposed argument is valid or not.

Children.applying proof strategy: Carrying out a given proof strategy to prove a given statement
Children.identifying proof strategy in proof: Identifying the proof strategies used in a given proof
Children.logical structure to proof strategy: Identifying which proof strategies are applicable to prove a given compound proposition based on its logical structure
Children.universal generalization: Carrying out a universal generalization argument to prove that a universal statement is true
Children.using proofs to evaluate: Using proofs to as knowledge discovery tools to decide whether a statement is true or false
Children.contradiction proofs: Tracing and/or modifying a proof by contradiction

Recursion and Induction.Description: Work with recursively defined data and prove their properties using inductive reasonging

Children.recursive definitions: Using a recursive definition to evaluate a function or determine membership in a set
Children.mathematical induction proofs: Using mathematical induction to prove mathematical identities, inequalities, and other invariants
Children.strong induction proofs: Using strong induction to prove mathematical identities, inequalities, and other invariants
Children.structural induction proofs: Using structural induction to prove statements about recursively defined objects, e.g. strings and trees

Children.congruence mod n: Applying the definition of congruence modulo n and modular arithmetic
Children.div and mod: Using the definitions of the div and mod operators on integers

Communication.Description: Clearly and unambiguously communicate computational ideas using appropriate formalism. Translate across levels of abstraction.

Use language conventions to improve argu.Description: Use precise language to clearly present logical arguments and communicate with technical and non-technical colleagues.

Children.tautologies and contradictions: Distinguishing between tautologies, contradictions, and contingencies
Children.binary relations properties: Determining whether a given binary relation is symmetric, antisymmetric, reflexive, and/or transitive
Children.function properties: Determining whether a given function is one-to-one, onto, and/or invertible
Children.special binary relations: Determining whether a given binary relation is an equivalence relation and/or a partial order
Children.induction flavors: Distinguishing between structural induction, mathematical induction, and strong induction
Children.proof signposts: Using appropriate signpost words to improve readability of proofs, including 'arbitrary' and 'assume'

Mathematical definitions and notation.Description: Use precise notation to encode meaning and present arguments concisely and clearly

Children.truth table definitions: Listing the truth tables of atomic boolean functions (and, or, xor, not, if, iff)
Children.write set definition: Precisely describing a set using appropriate notation e.g. roster method, set builder notation, and recursive definitions
Children.classify cardinality: Classifying sets into: finite sets, countably infinite sets, uncountable sets
Children.function and relation definitions: Defining functions, predicates, and binary relations using multiple representations
Children.functions for cardinality: Using functions to compare cardinality of sets
Children.important sets: Defining important sets of numbers, e.g. set of integers, set of rational numbers
